text: Family Member: February fifth till – Doctor: Oh yeah, because even if you start in January, it’s monthly, so. Family Member: So February fifth till like the twenty, till like the twenty-second or something. Doctor: Oh that’s fine. That’s fine. Family Member: So we have to schedule that around then. Doctor: Oh yeah, he’ll, trust me, we will hunt you down. He will hunt you down because every time you’re about to get a dose, it’s fifteen thousand dollars a dose. Family Member: Oh my god! Doctor: When I say we got to get insurance right, we got to get insurance right. But we also, they don’t mix it; they don’t pop the tab unless you’re around because there’s no re-do. Once you (makes sound) Family Member: So, so. Is this going to make him sleepless, like you said a little more energy? Doctor: No, no, it’s only going to help with pain and I think when you get off the Xtandi you’ll actually have more energy because no matter what that Xtandi is making you tired. Patient: Well my energy level isn’t bad. Doctor: Yeah, to you, but we’ve got this one over here going “Heh?” (Chuckles)

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um okay. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Who become resistant to hormones. Patient: Yeah, you talked about that. Doctor: And one of the things we’re observing is men who have BRCA2 mutation seem to respond really well to getting testosterone. We’re trying to figure out why. We just put in a big grant to kind of study this. So, so, we are about to, uh, have some trials where we’re – one of our trials is, if a guy has a mutation in this and he maybe responds to testosterone and he maybe responds to immune therapy, what if we give him both? Um. So, that’s a trial down the road that’s going to open up, um, probably in the next six months. We can talk more about that. Patient: If you get the grant? Doctor: No, we got that already. Patient: Oh.

text: Family Member: Monday, the eleventh. HCP Thank you. Doctor: Okay, you did start physical therapy? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is that going? Is it inducing more pain? Patient: That’s what I’m thinking it might be from right, right. Doctor: No, sometimes - Family Member: Sometimes, yeah. text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So if you have one of those gasping things, if it’s your old gasping problem or is it the new drug? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So then we’re going to put you on steroids and stuff like that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It can attack your colon so then you can have just profuse, non-stop diarrhea and so that we have to stop as well. It can attack your liver so then you get a hepatitis- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
